item.title: Advent of Code 2016
item.description: Solutions to the coding puzzle site's 25 daily puzzles.

item.title: Translating English Sentences into Propositional Logic Statements
item.description: Automatically converting informal English sentences into formal Propositional Logic.

item.title: Even Longer Longest Palindrome
item.description: Updating the palindrome program to search letter-by-letter; thus finding a longer palindrome.

item.title: On the (Small) Number of Atoms in the Universe
item.description: On the difference between counting things and counting combinations of things.

item.title: The Strength in Numbers Theorem
item.description: Update to my probability notebook, adding the Central Limit Theorem, also known as the Strength in Numbers Theorem.

item.title: WWW: Will Warriors Win?
item.description: Will the Warriors win the NBA title?

item.title: Go, Dog. Gauguin! The P. D. Eastman Story
item.description: The untold story of the children's book author/illustrator.

item.title: Countdown to 2016
item.description: Solving the equation 10 _ 9 _ 8 _ 7 _ 6 _ 5 _ 4 _ 3 _ 2 _ 1 = 2016. From an Alex Bellos puzzle.

item.title: Refactoring a Crossword Game Program
item.description: Refactoring the Scrabble / Wrds with Friends game from Udacity CS 212.

item.title: Beal's Conjecture Revisited
item.description: Updating the work I did in 2000 to search for counterexamples to Beal's Conjecture. Lists some of the things that people do wrong in trying to settle the conjecture.

item.title: Probability, Paradox, and the Reasonable Person Principle
item.description: An IPython notebook tutorial on Probability Paradoxes

item.title: Let's Code About Bike Locks
item.description: How many words can be made from a letter-based combination lock?

item.title: When Cheryl Met Eve: A Birthday Story
item.description: An extended exploration beyond the popular "Cheryl's Birthday" logic puzzle.

item.title: Cheryl's Birthday (How to Solve It with Code)
item.description: A solution to the popular "Cheryl's Birthday" logic puzzle.

item.title: LI2: Lego Institute for Lego Investigation
item.description: Web site for a new research institute.

item.title: Sol Golomb's Rectangle Puzzle
item.description: How many ways can you pack rectangles into a square? And other combinatorial problems ...

item.title: xkcd 1313: Regex Golf (Part 2: Infinite Problems)
item.description: Newly updated and improved version of my code to implement a meta-regex-golf program based on xkcd comic #1313. The code is "a program that plays regex golf with arbitrary lists..."

item.title: xkcd 1313: Regex Golf
item.description: Code to implement a meta-regex-golf program based on xkcd comic #1313. The code is "a program that plays regex golf with arbitrary lists..."

item.title: Letter Frequencies for Scrabble
item.description: An analysis of frequency counts for letters in English, with applications to the game of Scrabble. Also presents a distillation of the Google Books Ngram data, broken out by time periods.

item.title: Photos of Costa Rica Wildlife
item.description: Photos from a trip to Costa Rica with wildlife photographer Suzi Eszterhas.

item.title: English Letter Frequency Counts: Mayzner Revisited or ETAOIN SRHLDCU
item.description: An analysis of frequency counts for letters and letter sequences (n-grams), with counts broken out by length of word and poition in word, as well as by length of ngram. A re-implementation of the work done by Mark Mayzner in the 1960s -- but this time with 30 million times more data.

item.title: FAQ for the 2012 US Presidential Election (#FF00FF)
item.description: Added questions about early voting and state/federal to my frequently-asked-question list for the 2012 United States Presidential Election; all questions are answered with facts that are as objective as I can make them, except for the last question, in which I endorse President Obama.

item.title: FAQ for the 2012 US Presidential Election (#FF00FF)
item.description: A frequently-asked-question list for the 2012 United States Presidential Election; all questions are answered with facts that are as objective as I can make them, except for the last question, in which I endorse President Obama.

item.title: Intro to Statistics
item.description: This is not actually mine; it is a class by my co-teacher, Sebastian Thrun, on Intro to Statistics. I mention it because I think statistics is one of the most under-appreciated topics; everyone should learn statistics!

item.title: Peter Norvig: The 100,000-student classroom
item.description: My talk at the TED conference. Six minute video.

item.title: Google's Hybrid Approach to Research
item.description: An article printed in the Communications of the ACM describing Google's research, both within Google Research and within Engineering as a whole. Alfred Spector, Peter Norvig and Slav Petrov.

item.title: Prescient but Not Perfect: A Look Back at a 1966 Scientific American Article on Systems Analysis
item.description: My thoughts on a 1966 Scientific American article that was my introduction to programming. And if you ever need a CPL compiler, this is a good place to start.

item.title: Strachey's Checkers program from 1966
item.description: The source code to accompany my essay on Strachey's Scientific American article.

item.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
item.description: Sebastian Thrun and I are teaching an AI class online; 126,000 people have signed up so far.

item.title: On Chomsky and the Two Cultures of Statistical Learning
item.description: At the MIT 150 symposium, Chomsky said that the notion of success used by statistical language models (namely, that they successfully predict the world and allow programs to accomplish tasks) was "very novel ... I don't know of anything like it in the history of science." This essay argues that it is not novel at all, but perfectly commonplace.

item.title: Dance Photography
item.description: An overview of photographic techniques for taking pictures of indoor dance performances. (Also useful for any indoor action photography.)

item.title: (An ((Even Better) Lisp) Interpreter (in Python))
item.description: A new version of Lispy (Lisp interpreter in Python). I released an earlier version on Sept. 30th, but this version is improved.

item.title: (How to Write a (Lisp) Interpreter (in Python))
item.description: A Lisp interpreter in 90 lines of Python

item.title: The Odds of Finding a Set in The Card Game SET
item.description: Correcting an error in the instruction booklet for the card game SET

item.title: All we want are the facts, ma'am
item.description: On the lost art of fact-checking, and Chris Anderson's Wired Magazine article on The End of Theory

item.title: Lieberman, Egg, Sausage and Lieberman
item.description: A reply to Nate Silver's jungle primary post

item.title: An Exercise in Species Barcoding
item.description: Just in time for Darwin's birthday: an exercise in analyzing the differences in genomes to detect the boundaries between species

item.title: Election final predictions -- Part of my FAQ for the 2008 Election
item.description: Final prediction for electoral and popular votes: 353-185; 54-45%

item.description: Does McCain have a path to win? A state-by-state analysis.

item.title: What are imaginary reasons McCain might win? FAQ for the 2008 Election
item.description: Here are some reasons based onhope, not reason.

item.title: Election 2008 Dashboard
item.description: A collection of charts, poll results, and links, for the obsessive election junkie.

item.title: How accurate are polls? FAQ for the 2008 Presidential Election
item.description: New question for my FAQ answers "How accurate are polls?"

item.description: New question: "What about the economy" for FF00FF, my FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election.

item.description: New question: "Why are there so many negative attacks on both sides?" for FF00FF, my FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election.

item.description: New question: "Does race matter?" for FF00FF, my FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election.

item.title: Is the media biased? FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election
item.description: New question: "Is the media biased?" for my FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election. Tells you where to get information and compares the candidates.

item.description: New question: "Is it rational to vote?" for my FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election. Tells you where to get information and compares the candidates.

item.description: An FAQ for the 2008 US Presidential Election. Tells you where to get information and compares the candidates.

item.title: Beauty and the Geek Game Theory: Answering the Freakonomics Challenge
item.description: Answering Alon Nir's Freakonomics Challenge: What strategy to use on the TV show Beauty and the Geek

item.title: Galapagos Photography
item.description: Notes on what camera equipment to take to Galapagos, and links to my galleries.

item.title: Hiring a President II: Why I Endorse Obama
item.description: How to hire a president as if we were interviewing for CEO of a company: the 2008 edition.

item.title: Update to world's longest palindrome sentence
item.description: I update my palindrome page, and list a slightly longer one.

item.title: Evaluating Extraordinary Claims: Mind Over Matter? Or Mind Over Mind?
item.description: A companion to my essay on experiment design, this essay uses as an example the literature on the efficacy of intercessory prayer on medical conditions.

item.title: Warning Signs in Experimental Design and Interpretation
item.description: An update to my essay on experiment design; it now stresses warning signs rather than clear-cut mistakes and urges the reader to consider the factors that dilute the credibility of an experiment.

item.title: How to Write a Spelling Corrector (in Python)
item.description: Theory and practice of spelling correction algorithms

item.description: Can you trust statistics about internet usage?

item.description: Web logs for my site for the year

item.title: The Game of Carcassonne and the Parity Problem
item.description: Making a pretty map using the Carcassonne tiles; and figure out when you can't.

item.description: Commencement address for U.C. Berkeley Computer Science, May 2006

item.title: Norwegian translation of Teach Yourself Programming
item.description: Norwegian translation of my Teach Yourself Programming in Ten Years essay

item.description: Plot synopses for episodes of a Gilligan's Island remake starring members of the Bush Administration.

item.title: Solving Every Sudoku Puzzle
item.description: Python code and an explanation of how to solve any Sudoku puzzle.

item.title: Reporters and parrots

item.description: Romanian translation of this essay done by Ştefan Lazăr

item.title: The Global Climate Change Consensus: My Experiment
item.description: Do your own research! Confirm or deny the global climate change consensus! Here's how I did it.

item.description: The annual performance review for the guy who had a REALLY big year in '05.
